segment.source: Reference
segment.target: Reference

segment.source: The Account lockout threshold policy setting determines the number of failed sign-in attempts that will cause a user account to be locked.
segment.target: The Account lockout threshold policy setting determines the number of failed sign-in attempts that will cause a user account to be locked.

segment.source: A locked account cannot be used until you reset it or until the number of minutes specified by the Account lockout duration policy setting expires.
segment.target: A locked account cannot be used until you reset it or until the number of minutes specified by the Account lockout duration policy setting expires.

segment.source: You can set a value from 1 through 999 failed sign-in attempts, or you can specify that the account will never be locked by setting the value to 0.
segment.target: You can set a value from 1 through 999 failed sign-in attempts, or you can specify that the account will never be locked by setting the value to 0.

segment.source: If Account lockout threshold is set to a number greater than zero, Account lockout duration must be greater than or equal to the value of Reset account lockout counter after.
segment.target: If Account lockout threshold is set to a number greater than zero, Account lockout duration must be greater than or equal to the value of Reset account lockout counter after.

segment.source: Failed password attempts on workstations or member servers that have been locked by using CTRL+ALT+DELETE or password-protected screen savers do not count as failed sign-in attempts unless Interactive logon: Require Domain Controller authentication to unlock workstation is set to Enabled.
segment.target: Failed password attempts on workstations or member servers that have been locked by using CTRL+ALT+DELETE or password-protected screen savers do not count as failed sign-in attempts unless Interactive logon: Require Domain Controller authentication to unlock workstation is set to Enabled.

segment.source: If Interactive logon: Require Domain Controller authentication to unlock workstation is enabled, repeated failed password attempts to unlock the workstation will count against the account lockout threshold.
segment.target: If Interactive logon: Require Domain Controller authentication to unlock workstation is enabled, repeated failed password attempts to unlock the workstation will count against the account lockout threshold.

segment.source: Brute force password attacks can be automated to try thousands or even millions of password combinations for any or all user accounts.
segment.target: Brute force password attacks can be automated to try thousands or even millions of password combinations for any or all user accounts.

segment.source: Limiting the number of failed sign-ins that can be performed nearly eliminates the effectiveness of such attacks.
segment.target: Limiting the number of failed sign-ins that can be performed nearly eliminates the effectiveness of such attacks.

segment.source: However, it is important to note that a denial-of-service (DoS) attack could be performed on a domain that has an account lockout threshold configured.
segment.target: However, it is important to note that a denial-of-service (DoS) attack could be performed on a domain that has an account lockout threshold configured.

segment.source: A malicious user could programmatically attempt a series of password attacks against all users in the organization.
segment.target: A malicious user could programmatically attempt a series of password attacks against all users in the organization.

segment.source: If the number of attempts is greater than the value of Account lockout threshold, the attacker could potentially lock every account.
segment.target: If the number of attempts is greater than the value of Account lockout threshold, the attacker could potentially lock every account.

segment.source: Vulnerability
segment.target: Vulnerability

segment.source: Brute force password attacks can use automated methods to try millions of password combinations for any user account.
segment.target: Brute force password attacks can use automated methods to try millions of password combinations for any user account.

segment.source: The effectiveness of such attacks can be almost eliminated if you limit the number of failed sign-in attempts that can be performed.
segment.target: The effectiveness of such attacks can be almost eliminated if you limit the number of failed sign-in attempts that can be performed.

segment.source: However, a DoS attack could be performed on a domain that has an account lockout threshold configured.
segment.target: However, a DoS attack could be performed on a domain that has an account lockout threshold configured.

segment.source: An attacker could programmatically attempt a series of password attacks against all users in the organization.
segment.target: An attacker could programmatically attempt a series of password attacks against all users in the organization.

segment.source: If the number of attempts is greater than the account lockout threshold, the attacker might be able to lock every account without needing any special privileges or being authenticated in the network.
segment.target: If the number of attempts is greater than the account lockout threshold, the attacker might be able to lock every account without needing any special privileges or being authenticated in the network.

segment.source: Note: Offline password attacks are not countered by this policy setting.
segment.target: Note: Offline password attacks are not countered by this policy setting.

segment.source: Countermeasure
segment.target: Countermeasure

segment.source: Because vulnerabilities can exist when this value is configured and when it is not configured, two distinct countermeasures are defined.
segment.target: Because vulnerabilities can exist when this value is configured and when it is not configured, two distinct countermeasures are defined.

segment.source: Organizations should weigh the choice between the two, based on their identified threats and the risks that they want to mitigate.
segment.target: Organizations should weigh the choice between the two, based on their identified threats and the risks that they want to mitigate.

segment.source: The two countermeasure options are:
segment.target: The two countermeasure options are:

segment.source: Configure the Account lockout threshold setting to 0.
segment.target: Configure the Account lockout threshold setting to 0.

segment.source: This configuration ensures that accounts will not be locked, and it will prevent a DoS attack that intentionally attempts to lock accounts.
segment.target: This configuration ensures that accounts will not be locked, and it will prevent a DoS attack that intentionally attempts to lock accounts.

segment.source: This configuration also helps reduce Help Desk calls because users cannot accidentally lock themselves out of their accounts.
segment.target: This configuration also helps reduce Help Desk calls because users cannot accidentally lock themselves out of their accounts.

segment.source: Because it does not prevent a brute force attack, this configuration should be chosen only if both of the following criteria are explicitly met:
segment.target: Because it does not prevent a brute force attack, this configuration should be chosen only if both of the following criteria are explicitly met:

segment.source: The password policy setting requires all users to have complex passwords of 8 or more characters.
segment.target: The password policy setting requires all users to have complex passwords of 8 or more characters.

segment.source: A robust audit mechanism is in place to alert administrators when a series of failed sign-ins occur in the environment.
segment.target: A robust audit mechanism is in place to alert administrators when a series of failed sign-ins occur in the environment.

segment.source: Configure the Account lockout threshold policy setting to a sufficiently high value to provide users with the ability to accidentally mistype their password several times before the account is locked, but ensure that a brute force password attack still locks the account.
segment.target: Configure the Account lockout threshold policy setting to a sufficiently high value to provide users with the ability to accidentally mistype their password several times before the account is locked, but ensure that a brute force password attack still locks the account.

segment.source: A good recommendation for such a configuration is 50 invalid sign-in attempts, which prevents accidental account lockouts and reduces the number of Help Desk calls, but does not prevent a DoS attack.
segment.target: A good recommendation for such a configuration is 50 invalid sign-in attempts, which prevents accidental account lockouts and reduces the number of Help Desk calls, but does not prevent a DoS attack.

segment.source: We recommend this option if your organization cannot implement complex password requirements and an audit policy that alerts administrators to a series of failed sign-in attempts.
segment.target: We recommend this option if your organization cannot implement complex password requirements and an audit policy that alerts administrators to a series of failed sign-in attempts.

segment.source: Using this type of policy must be accompanied by a process to unlock locked accounts.
segment.target: Using this type of policy must be accompanied by a process to unlock locked accounts.

segment.source: It must be possible to implement this policy whenever it is needed to help mitigate massive lockouts caused by an attack on your systems.
segment.target: It must be possible to implement this policy whenever it is needed to help mitigate massive lockouts caused by an attack on your systems.

segment.source: Potential impact
segment.target: Potential impact

segment.source: If this policy setting is enabled, a locked account is not usable until it is reset by an administrator or until the account lockout duration expires.
segment.target: If this policy setting is enabled, a locked account is not usable until it is reset by an administrator or until the account lockout duration expires.

segment.source: Enabling this setting will likely generate a number of additional Help Desk calls.
segment.target: Enabling this setting will likely generate a number of additional Help Desk calls.

segment.source: If you configure the Account lockout threshold policy setting to 0, there is a possibility that an malicious user's attempt to discover passwords with a brute force password attack might go undetected if a robust audit mechanism is not in place.
segment.target: If you configure the Account lockout threshold policy setting to 0, there is a possibility that an malicious user's attempt to discover passwords with a brute force password attack might go undetected if a robust audit mechanism is not in place.

segment.source: If you configure this policy setting to a number greater than 0, an attacker can easily lock any accounts for which the account name is known.
segment.target: If you configure this policy setting to a number greater than 0, an attacker can easily lock any accounts for which the account name is known.

segment.source: This is especially dangerous considering that no credentials other than access to the network are necessary to lock the accounts.
segment.target: This is especially dangerous considering that no credentials other than access to the network are necessary to lock the accounts.
